sentence: Share prices of homebuilders gained on Tuesday, Feb 24, amid a string of positive housing related news.
To begin with, the S&P/Case-Shiller 20-city home price index grew 4.5% year over year in December, slightly higher than 4.3% in November.
The December increase was better than general market expectations.
Another trigger to the rally could be the better-than-expected earnings and sales results posted by luxury homebuilder, Toll Brothers, Inc. ( TOL ).
The company beat the Zacks Consensus Estimate for both earnings and sales in the first quarter of fiscal 2015, backed by higher pricing and strong margins.
Toll Brothers also noted that the spring selling season was off to a good start and expects robust housing demand going forward.
Toll Brothers' shares rose almost 4% on Tuesday.
Another homebuilder, Meritage Homes Corp. ( MTH ) announced that its January new home orders surged 48%.
The stock spiked more than 5% on Tuesday.
The Home Depot, Inc. ( HD ) -- which also reported on Tuesday -- also beat the Zacks Consensus Estimate for both earnings and sales in the fourth quarter of 2014.
The company ended 2014 on a high note with better-than-expected bottom-line results in each of its four quarters.
This followed a U.S. housing market recovery and strength in core store activities.
Following a spectacular year, Home Depot hiked its quarterly dividend, announced new capital allocation plans and issued a favorable guidance for 2015.
Other housing stocks like PulteGroup, Inc. ( PHM ), Lennar Corporation ( LEN ), D.R.
Horton, Inc. ( DHI ), Beazer Homes USA Inc. ( BZH ), Ryland Group Inc. ( RYL ), NVR, Inc. ( NVR ) and KB Home ( KBH ) all rose on Tuesday, reflecting an overall upbeat sentiment among the builders.
The general market trend indicates that homebuilding activity will pick up in 2015 as the job numbers improve and the economy gets more reassuring.
Moreover, improving consumer confidence, moderating home price gains, affordable interest rates, higher rentals and a limited supply of inventory should help release pent-up demand this year.
As housing demand stabilized, housing price gains slowed in 2014, which is expected to continue in 2015.
Moreover, analysts are predicting that with rising home prices, it will be difficult for the millennials to pay the down payment which has been rising too.
So instead of buying, they will rent, in turn increasing the rents.
Moreover, even if mortgage rates rise in the latter half of the year - as is widely anticipated - these should still remain reasonable.
To conclude, falling fuel prices and a rebounding economy have greatly increased purchasing power and with it the desire to own new homes.
